spanishExample: ¡Hágalo! Ni él ni ella lo harán.
englishTranslation: (formal) Do it! Neither he nor she will do it.
vocabIncluded: harán: __, they will __ (Hacer, future, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Hazlo! *Earlier* hacías todo lo que te *we told.*
englishTranslation: Do it! Earlier you used to do everything that we told you.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hacías: "were doing/making", "you were doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 2nd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: ¡Haz lo que te *they tell!* Ellos no lo hacen.
englishTranslation: Do what they tell you! They don’t do it.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Ella hacía eso *before*, pero ahora no lo haría.
englishTranslation: She used to do that before, but now she would not do it.
vocabIncluded: hacía: "was doing/making", "he/she/it was doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 3rd person)
haría: "would do/make", "he/she/it would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Así que no fuiste? Hasta ellos fueron.
englishTranslation: So you didn’t go? Even they went.

spanishExample: Eso tiene que hacerse hasta ese año.
englishTranslation: That has to be done until that year.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Ellos lo tienen todo sí o sí.
englishTranslation: They have it all either way.
vocabIncluded: lo + Tener + todo: "to have it all" (idiom)

spanishExample: Ellos nunca *wanted* hacerte ese favor.
englishTranslation: They never wanted to do you that favor.

spanishExample: ¿Cómo que lo haremos nosotros?
englishTranslation: What do you mean we will do it?
vocabIncluded: haremos: "will do/make", "we will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: ¿Quién va a ir? Tú lo hiciste otra vez.
englishTranslation: Who is going to go? You did it another time.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¿Lo hará otro día?
englishTranslation: Will he do it another day?
vocabIncluded: hará: "will do/make", "he/she/it will do/make" (Hacer, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Tú no lo harás?
englishTranslation: You won’t do it?
vocabIncluded: harás: "will do/make", "you will do/make" (Hacer, future, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Hay que hacerle ese favor.
englishTranslation: There's a need to do her that favor.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: Hice eso para tenerte.
englishTranslation: I did that in order to have you.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: *I want* que tú hagas eso cuando ellos también lo hagan.
englishTranslation: I want you to do that when they also do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Juan hace eso, pero yo también lo haría.
englishTranslation: Juan does that, but I would also do it.
vocabIncluded: haría: "would do/make", "I would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Lo haré, pero cuando lo haga, no estaré ahí.
englishTranslation: I will do it, but when I do it, I won’t be there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estaré: "will be", "I will be" (Estar, future, 1st person)
haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Mi amigo tenía que tenerlo y por eso hizo eso.
englishTranslation: My friend had to have it and that’s why he did that.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No *you want* irte.
englishTranslation: You don’t want to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Nuestros amigos hicieron muchas cosas en la casa.
englishTranslation: Our friends did a lot of things in the house.

spanishExample: *They want* que él haga eso y esté por ahí.
englishTranslation: They want him to do that and to be around.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Si hacemos eso, tendremos que irnos.
englishTranslation: If we do that, we’ll have to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
tendremos: "will have", "we will have" (Tener, future, 1st person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Siempre hago eso, pero él no *wants* irse.
englishTranslation: I always do that, but he doesn’t want to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Siempre lo hacía.
englishTranslation: I always used to do it.
vocabIncluded: hacía: "was doing/making", "I was doing/making" (Hacer, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Ya lo hicimos, pero tenemos que hacerlo otra vez.
englishTranslation: We already did it, but we have to do it again.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Ya que haces eso, *I want* irme.
englishTranslation: Since you do that, I want to leave.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense
